actor1: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
actor2: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
source: Xinhua; RFI; Voice of America; Associated Press International; Reuters
notes: On February 3rd, inter-ethnic fighting broke out in Blukwa, around 100km from Bunia, between the Hema and Lendu militias. The attack lasted two days and at least 23 members of the Hema community were killed by Lendu (although reports differ, ranging from 23-32), 12 people were severely injured and several houses were burned during the attack on the Hema village. Police and soldiers were dispatched to the spot to prevent the spread of violence, which followed days of tension between the two ethnic communities in the region.

actor1: Lubumbashi Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On the night of April 21, unidentified armed men with the intention of looting broke into a house and killed a woman and her baby in the Kisanga area of Lubumbashi. Similar attacks are reported to occur daily in Lubmbashi.

actor1: Kalehe Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)

actor1: Unidentified Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On April 4, unidentified men who tried to steal fishing material killed a 34 year old man on Kivu Lake, close to Chondo village in Kalehe.

On June 10, two factions of the Mayi Mayi Kifuafua (the original group led by Delphin Mbaenda and another splinter group led by Shario Shemono Ngendo) in Busurungi. Clashes spread to other areas the following day. 8 people killed in total including 7 on the second day. The Ngendo faction leader, Shalio was among the casualties.

On May 15, unidentified armed men attacked Mirangi, in Rutshuru, to steal cows. The Nyatura Domi were alerted by the population and intervened to prevent the looting. During the clash, 4 shepherds were killed and 5 injured. 30 cows were stolen.

The same source reports that a sergeant from the FARDC was killed, another soldier injured and 2 AK-47s taken by the FRPI.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On 8 March, the FARDC destroyed a Mayi Mayi camp in Tingbe Forest near Eringiti, Beni. 2 rebels were killed and three other captured.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)

Upon hearing about this, several youth came to the streets, attacking the police station. 2 policemen were taken hostages and one was burned alive.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)

actor2: Bafulero Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On July 5, the local Mayi Mayi militia attacked an army post 30km north of Lake Edward. 3 rebels died during the attack.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)

On 12 March, the Mayi Mayi Mazembe killed a 46 year old man in Kanyatsi.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)

actor2: Aru Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)

Suspected Islamist Ugandan rebels (ADF) killed three civilians in Kokola on January 21st. The victims were a taxi driver and his two customers.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

Army intervened on or before July 18th, taking back control of Kahira and Kamiro.

actor1: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: Protests called by the CLC to denounce the prolonged stay of President Kabila take place in Kinshasa and a number of cities across DRC despite being banned by the government. Police fired live bullets and tear gas in Kinshasa leaving two protesters seriously injured and two others killed. The DRC government blocked all access to internet and SMS during the protests. MONUSCO reports 100 arrests during the protests. PPRDYL members are also accused of having vandalised the national HQ of the CLC in Burumbu.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On April 2, FARDC soldiers killed four civilians in the mining centre of Salamabila, in the territory of Kabambare.
Presumed ADF rebels attacked the village of Mangolikene, in the south of Beni, killing 8. 10 people are currently missing.

actor1: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On June 13, an argument between a police officer and a civilian over the candidacy of Vital Kamerhe in Walungu led the police officer to shoot the civilian, who died. After the incident, residents gathered and killed the policeman.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)

actor1: Beni Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)

actor1: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
notes: On the night of April 8-9, the FRPI attacked the village of Kandana Singo in Walendu Bindi, Irumu. The attackers pillaged the village and scared the population off, who fled to nearby locations. During the attacks and the robberies, one merchant was killed.

On June 11, two factions of the Mayi Mayi Kifuafua (the original group led by Delphin Mbaenda and another splinter group led by Shario Shemono Ngendo) clashed in Waloa Loanda, Biriko, Kilambo, Kifuruka and Busurungi in Walikale. 7 reported deaths (4 militiamen and 3 civilians).

actor1: Banyamulenge Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
actor2: Bafulero Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: Report of clashes between the Banyamulenge and Bafulero groups in Uvira starting on April 30. 8 people were killed over 30 April-5 May. On 6 May, the two groups clashed again in Banyamulenge, also Uvira, leaving another two killed.

actor1: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On 15 March, the head of the police in Mudzi Pela, Bunia, was killed in an IDP camp by revolting IDPs. The police officer went to the rescue of provincial minister Didi Angaika, who had been taken hostage by the IDPs in the camp, during his visit accompanied by the National Institute of Professional Preparation. The minister and some others in his delegation were taken hostages, and when the police intervened, they used tear gas and shots in the air to disperse the crowd. The head of the police was nonetheless hit by a stone in the head, falling dead just after.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On January 7th, clashes between the FARDC and the Mayi Mayi Hapa na pale resulted in the death of five persons. The attack took place in the villages of Numbi, Mbeya and Masumbalungu, in Kilembwe. The victims are 2 militiamen and 3 civilians, which include the Kilembwe traditional chief and his sons.

actor1: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
actor2: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: Unidentified armed men attacked Kabare and Walungu in South Kivu on February 26th. Disguised as civilians, they targeted a bistro near a parish in Kabare, killing 4 civilians and 1 policeman who tried to intervene. The FARDC only arrived when they had already escaped.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On the night of 23-24 May, a FARDC soldier was ambushed by the FNL between Kiliba and the grouping of Runingu. The soldier was killed while on patrol. The FARDC arrived after and the clash allegedly led to 3 rebel deaths.

On May 27, the Mayi Mayi Kifuafua Delphin shot two traders in Lukaraba village, Walikale. One person was killed on the spot and the other remained injured because they refused to carry the assailants' belongings.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
actor2: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On May 1, a convoy escorted by FARDC soldiers was attacked in Busendo, a dozen km away from Rutshuru centre. The attack led to an exchange of fire, which killed one woman. Three other civilians were injured as well as one soldier. Civil society claims that three rebels were killed as well.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: A new attack was perpetrated in Tchele, Djugu, by unidentified armed men on the night of February 26-27. 3 people were killed by machette, including one by civilians who took up arms to confront the group.

actor1: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: 20 February. In Djugu territory, Lendu youths reportedly killed four Hema civilians (two men and two girls) and one FARDC soldier and destroyed some 300 houses in the Tche area (16 km south of Blukwa). The violence has prompted significant population displacements within the province and towards neighbouring Uganda.

On 20 April, ADF gunmen killed a motorcycle driver and his client close to Tungudu village in Beni territory. They were on their way to Ndalya market in Ituri. The FARDC chased and attacked the ADF forces right after the attack, killing one ADF.

actor1: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: In Mbandaka, CLC protesters attacked the police during the protests called for by the CLC on February 25. 4 security officers were injured, as well as 4 rioters. One of the protesters was killed by a police officer while he was returning home. The police officer then fled the scene.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: Between January-April, report of over 10 targeted killings as well as kidnappings and looting by unknown gunmen stationed at Virunga National Park. 10 fatalities spread over four events between January and April.
On July 22, the ADF raided Mavivi town in Nord-Kivu. The attackers killed two people and injured five, looted cattle. 13 people went missing.

On June 11, two factions of the Mayi Mayi Kifuafua (the original group led by Delphin Mbaenda and another splinter group led by Shario Shemono Ngendo) clashed in Waloa Loanda, Biriko, Kilambo, Kifuruka and Busurungi in Walikale. 7 reported deaths (4 militiamen and 3 civilians).

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On May 1, a FARDC soldier killed a 72 year old man in Kavalala, Beni. When civilians were trying to recover the body, the FARDC shot trying to disperse them and injured another 6.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On May 9, armed men kidnapped five women and five men from Mbongya, Mabambila and Nyaleke villages in Beni. On the same day, unidentified armed men killed a man in Malolu village, Beni.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: Around 5 May, 5 people from the ONG 'Movement for the Development of the Kasai' have died in Kananga trying to defuse explosives.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: 05 January. Mai-Mai elements attacked an FARDC position near Uvira, killing four FARDC soldiers and five national police officers.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On January 1st, the FARDC clashed with the Mayi Mayi Kilalo in Mabuya, Beni, leading to 2 deaths (one on each side).
The Mayi Mayi Nyatura attacked the Mazembe in Kalusi (Goma) and Kanyasi. 9 civilians were killed and at least 2 rebels were shot dead.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On July 7, unidentified gunmen killed a 68-year-old woman in her field in the Sayo neighborhood of Beni town. Circumstances unclear.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On July 5, 5 ADF rebels died in Mwalika after attacking the FARDC.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
actor2: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On April 22, a soldier killed another soldier in the Boikene neighbourhood of Beni. One soldier had misbehaved, and the FARDC deployed a platoon to address the issue. The platoon commander tried to reprimand him, but was shot and died.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On June 21, unidentified men broke into a house in Kasenyi village, Nyiragongo, and killed a man.

actor1: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: After the police officer shot against one of the protesters on January 29th, these became violent, managed to get one of the police officers and lynched him in the open.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: The FARDC and presumed Mayi Mayi clashed on January 2nd near the airport of Kananga. 3 deaths were reported.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
actor2: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On April 23, unidentified armed men attacked the FARDC position in Ntoto. One soldier and one assailant died.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On July 13, unidentified gunmen raided a house in Bwatsinge village in Lubero territory during the night. The attackers shot and killed a 24-year-old man.

On May 10, the Kamwina Nsapu killed 8 people in the locality of Mulombela, in Dibaya. They attacked around 13h, killing a couple and their 6 kids. Another report mentions that at least there were 4 deaths, but with a mention that a military source stated 8. On May 12, 8 deaths were confirmed. The head of the assassinated family is the brother of the current village chief. The militia was headed by David Ndaye Kalonga, a.k.a. Nsabanga.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
actor2: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
notes: The FARDC and FRPI clashed in the chiefdom of Walendu Bindi, in Ituri, on February 22nd. The FRPI attacked with 5 men through pillaging the population and their houses. At that point, the FARDC was alerted and tried to repel the militiamen. One of the soldiers was killed as well as a civilian.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: Between January-April, report of over 10 targeted killings as well as kidnappings and looting by unknown gunmen stationed at Virunga National Park. 10 fatalities spread over four events between January and April.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On 8 March, unidentified armed men raped and killed a 16 year old girl in Sake, Masisi.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On March 19, unidentified armed men killed a man in Kilolirwe, Masisi territory.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On March 2, a 50 year old woman was raped and strangled to death in the village of Chumirwa, in Shabunda.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: In April, two more people killed by unidentified armed in Kalehe area. Human rights associations claim there are several displaced people in the area armed with fire weapons. They seem to have settled in Ramba.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On May 10, unidenified gunmen broke into the house of the local chief in Nyakibamba, Idjwi, and killed him. A man and a boy were also killed during their runaway.

actor1: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy
notes: On June 12, the NDC Guidon and the CNRD clashed in Kinyabwitsi, Walikale territory. 2 CNRD and 1 NDC Guidon died.

actor1: FDLR-Rude: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda (Rude Faction)
notes: On May 26, 9 people were abducted not far from Kiwanja. One of them was killed when he resisted the kidnapping. The suspected assailants are the FDLR/Rudi.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
actor2: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On July 2, a convoy was attacked by an unidentified group while carrying 17 detainees in the Rugari sector, 40km north of Goma. 1 FARDC soldier was killed.

actor1: Unidentified Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: 2 people were killed by machetes and axes on the night of January 4-5, in the village of Rukaza, in Matanda. The killing is alledgedly due to land disputes going on in the region.

Around 8 July, 8 fishermen were accosted by Ugandan soldiers in Lake Edward. A witness claims that his colleague fishermen were killed by the military. Another report mentions that at least 12 fishermen died and a dozen more are missing.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On March 29, two unidentified armed men killed a man in Goma.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On June 17, the FARDC were deployed to protect a magistrate in Malepe neighbourhood, Beni. They killed a known thief who climbed a wall in the location.
On July 7, the Ugandan army shot at 8 fishermen during a patrol in Lake Edward. 7 of them died, while the remaining fisherman played dead to escape the killing.

actor1: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: A policeman in Yakoma was tortured on February 9th by other policemen, who followed the orders or the colonel of Yakoma police station. The tortued policeman was accused of releasing a detainee, reason according to which the colonel ordered his torture. The victim died due to the injuries.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On July 12, unidentified gunmen shot and killed a 62-year-old woman in the Pasisi neighborhood of Beni city. The body of the victim was discovered with bullet wounds in her chest.

actor1: Twiganeho Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On July 5, the Twiganeho Banyamulenge ambushed and killed 3 people in the plains of Bujembo.

actor2: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On 15 April, the Nyatura FDP captured and killed a FARDC soldier in Rugari village in Rutshuru territory.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On the night of 12 March, unidentified armed men killed 41 people in 4 villages in Djugu, Ituri (Kayuba, Djo/Jo and Gbi - in Bahema Nord - and Ngaliko - in Walendu Tatsi. In Djugu, assailants burned houses before killing 10 people and moving on to Gbi.

actor1: FRPI: Front for Patriotic Resistance of Ituri
notes: On the night of July 8-9, suspected FRPI elements attacked the locality of Zamblite, in Walendu Tatsi, Ituri. They killed a civilian, raped a woman and injured another civilian.

actor1: MONUSCO: United Nations Organization Stabilization Mission in Democratic Republic of Congo (2010-)
actor2: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On 17 March, an armed group attacked a Uruguayan MONUSCO deployment in Djo at around 18h. 2 rebels were killed.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
actor2: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On 6 March, unidentified armed men killed a FARDC soldier in Kamukwale, Rutshuru.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On Monday, January 15th, the ADF attacked the FARDC in Munzambayi, commune of Rwenzori, where they were repelled. According to the FARDC, 5 people were injured (3 of which seriously) and 2 weapons were seized. A later testimony reports 3 FARDC deaths.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On July 2, unidentified men raped a 17 year old girl in Butembo town and then killed her.

On January 10th, armed men identified as Mayi-Mayi Kifuafua Delphin Mbaenda killed a woman in Mandje village in Walikale territory, accusing her of being a witch. The assailants looted the victim's house.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On April 22, the head of the Mayi Mayi Raia Mutomboki Mabala - Kikukala Wemba - was killed during a clash with the FARDC in Lutika. The rebels had gathered in Lutika after the attacks perpetrated in Bampinga and Parking the previous week. The clash lasted two hours, after which the chief Kikukala Wemba was shot. The other 12 rebels then fled, and Wemba succumbed to his injuries.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
actor2: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: Over 23-24 March, unknown assailants clashed with the FARDC in Penyi and Jeli in Djugu territory, Ituri. 14 confirmed killed including one soldier and 13 assailants. Other reports also mentioned an attack in Mbachulu, in Ituri.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On April 26, unidentified armed men killed a 40-year old man in Kibenete village, Rutshuru, when he was returning from the Kikuku market.

actor1: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
actor2: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On May 9, armed men shot and killed a policeman in Kisuma, and wounded another.

actor1: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
actor2: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: More than 60 people were killed during the previous week due to the interethnic conflicts between Hema and Lendu militias. 23 fatalities already reported in data.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On June 21, a student was killed by unidentified armed men in the commune of Kimeni, in Butembo.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
actor2: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: Unidentified armed men broke into a house in Mapendo, in Rutshuru territory, on January 10th, where they shot and killed a woman. In a nearby property, the assailants came across a policeman who shot at them. During the clash the policeman, a man and two women were killed; an infant was shot and wounded.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
actor2: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy
notes: On February 27th, the FARDC regained the position of Kashuga village, in Masisi, after attacking the CNRD there. One civilian died during the confrontation.

actor1: FDLR-RUD: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda-Rally for Unity and Democracy
notes: On 13 March, FDLR-RUD killed a man in Kahunga.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On the night of July 7, the ADF attacked in Beni. The FARDC counted several deaths and a massive displacement of the population. Reports mention at least 1 FARDC killed, several ADF rebels (unknown coded as 3) and also 2 MONUSCO soldiers.

Later the same day, when the hostages were being taken to an unkown location, they were attacked by another Nyatura faction in Ishola, near Nyanzala, where 2 of them were killed. The third hostage managed to escape while the fourth is still captured.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On July 19, unidentified armed men raided two houses in Masau village, Beni territory, at night. The attackers were looking for money. Failing to find any, the attackers shot and killed two men.

actor1: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy
notes: On June 24, the CNRD kidnapped three young boys from Katsiru village, brought them to their camp and then killed them.

actor2: Banyamulenge Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: Over 3-5 July, the Mayi Mayi, supported by Burundian groups like the Red Tabara and the Frodebu, clashed with the Bayamulenge in the city of Uvira. There were at least 20 deaths and 400 families impacted by the conflict.

On May 27, the NDC Guidon attacked the Mazembe in Lubero village. 3 NDC rebels were killed and another 4 injured. One Mazembe was injured and the NDC looted several goods, burning down part of the Mazembe camp.
On July 3, the Raia Mutomboki Mabala attacked Nyombe and killed a man, stealing also money and looting the village.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On April 18, a coalition of Raia Mutomboki Ndarumanga and Kokodikoko clashed with the FARDC in the mining site Parking, in Shabunda. The rebels arrived from the grouping of Baliga, and engaged in a 30 minute fire exchange, resulting in the killing of one soldier. Local workers and the population fled the site.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: Gunshots were heard on the morning of January 16th in the hill 'Tujenge', 12 km to the south of Baraka. Some passerby women were told by the FARDC to turn back when they were heading there. One of the women says she saw the dead body of a combatant on the ground. The Yakutumba claim 5 FARDC soldiers were killed, though this is unverified.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
actor2: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On 5 March, a FARDC soldier guarding a health centre was shot dead by an unidentified armed men who wanted to loot it. The attack took place in Kisharo, Rutshuru.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On May 28, the FARDC were attacked by the Mayi Mayi in Isale, Lubero. 2 rebels were neutralised.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On June 16, a military killed a civilian in the village of Kakamba, in Kazumba, when they were disputing a debt. The civilian's family subsequently seized the soldier and beat him to death.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On April 28 and 29, the Nyatura launched offensives in Rutshuru. On 29 April, the Nyatura attacked Kirumba (grouping Tongo). 2 soldiers were killed, one of which was a lieutenant, and 2 AK 47s were taken.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On May 18, unidentifed armed men killed the local chief - Mandra Mazibo - of the Kanvinvira area in Uvira.
On February 25, the Nyatura Love attacked the Mazembe in Kanyatsi. 2 Mayi Mayi died.

actor2: UPLC: Union of Patriots for the Liberation of Congo
notes: On January 25th, the FARDC launched an offensive against the UPLC in Kasindi-Lubiriha, 90km east of Beni. During the operation, one of the rebels was killed. A subsequent report mentions two deaths.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On May 21, a 41 year old man was killed in Lwango village, Kalehe, with a crude weapon.

On May 30, the NDC-Guidon attacked the Mazembe in Pitakongo village, Lubero. Three NDC-G rebels died and one was injured; one Mazembe was injured. The NDC-Guidon burned down the Mayi Mayi Mazembe camp.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On April 6, the FARDC attacked attacked the Mayi Mayi in Kalemie, with the intention of displacing them. The attack left 13 killed - 11 rebels and 2 soldiers - 3 captured rebels and 5 seized AK-47s.
On the night of June 9-10, local militiamen headed by warlord Makabe attacked the villagers of Mpela, grouping of Kisula, in Malemba Nkulu. 2 people reportedly killed and 48 houses burned.

actor1: Rutshuru Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On May 14, unidentified armen men tried to hold up a vehicle in Vitshumbi. The driver accelerated, and the rebels shot, killig the man.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On March 28, unidentified armed men broke into a house in Ibinza village, close to Izege, and killed two civilians.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

actor1: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On May 24, a Mayi Mayi militia attacked the Banro Corp's east Congo Namoya gold mine. During the attack, five people were killed (including 2 Congolese security force members) and many were wounded. It is the second attack in less than a year.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On April 6, the Mayi Mayi attacked the FARDC in Kasiki. Two soldiers and one civilian killed.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

Army intervened on or before July 18th, taking back control of Kahira and Kamiro.

notes: On June 24, unidentified gunmen killed a man in Majengo neighbourhood, in Goma.

notes: Report of clashes between the Banyamulenge and Bafulero groups in Uvira starting on April 30. 8 people were killed over 30 April-5 May. On 6 May, the two groups clashed again in Banyamulenge, also Uvira, leaving another two killed.

actor2: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On April 28 and 29, the Nyatura launched offensives in Rutshuru. On April 28, the attack was on Nyanzale (grouping Kihondo), where two people were killed during a clash with an unknown armed group.

actor1: CNRD: National Council for Renewal and Democracy
notes: On June 27, the CNRD killed a man in Katsiru village.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On 7 March, a FARDC soldier harassed civilians in Visusa village, close to Vuhombwe. He shot two men who wanted to alert security forces, and killed a 24 year old civilian, injuring also another 18 year old.

notes: Between 13 July and 17 July, alleged clashes between APCLS supported by Rwandan Hutus and Nduma Guidon in Masisi territory. 8 killed between Lukweti and Nyabiondo over the five days of fighting plus 7 killed (5 civilians and 2 Guidon members) on July 16th in Kamiro. actor2: Aru Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: Inhabitants of Rodo village in Aru got into clashes with one another over land disputes in the region. The clashes started on Wednesday and lasted for three days. On February 14-15, 6 people were killed with weapons and 6 others were injured in the village of Rodo.

actor1: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
actor2: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

actor1: Banyamulenge Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
actor2: Bafulero Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: Report of clashes between the Banyamulenge and Bafulero groups in Uvira starting on April 30. 8 people were killed over 30 April-5 May. On 6 May, the two groups clashed again in Banyamulenge, also Uvira, leaving another two killed.

actor1: FDLR-RUD: Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda-Rally for Unity and Democracy
notes: On March 26, the FDLR-RUD attacked a house in Rusaka 5 village, next to Nkwenda, demanding money. The owner of the house was then shot and killed because he did not comply with their orders.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On May 7, armed people attacked and killed man in Nzenga I village, Beni.

actor1: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
actor2: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

The attacks took place in Gobu, Songo Moya, Songa mbili and Tara.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
actor2: Unidentified Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On April 5, assailants stole 15 cows from Kizoki village, close to Makobola. The FARDC attacked the assailants and repelled them. One soldier was injured and one rebel killed.

actor1: Hema Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
actor2: Lendu Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
source: Xinhua; RFI; Voice of America; Associated Press International; Reuters
notes: On February 3rd, inter-ethnic fighting broke out in Blukwa, around 100km from Bunia, between the Hema and Lendu militias. The attack lasted two days and at least 23 members of the Hema community were killed by Lendu (although reports differ, ranging from 23-32), 12 people were severely injured and several houses were burned during the attack on the Hema village. Police and soldiers were dispatched to the spot to prevent the spread of violence, which followed days of tension between the two ethnic communities in the region.

actor2: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
notes: On 18 April, a clash broke out between APCLS and Nyatura Domi combatants at a meeting in Bunkuba village in Rutshuru territory. Four killed and one injured.

actor1: APCLS: Alliance of Patriots for a Free and Sovereign Congo
notes: On June 30, the APCLS attacked the NDC-Guidon and an APCLS/NDC-G coalition led by Mapenzi in Maniema, Walikale. 7 were left dead in the Mapenzi-Guidon coalition.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On 11 March, a woman was killed by unidentified armed men in Kisangani.

notes: On May 13, ANR agents arrested a man in Bulambo, Beni, for suspicion of him belonging to the Mayi Mayi Mazembe. The detainee was taken to the FARDC camp, where he was tortured and died. The FARDC burried the body without informing the family.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On 6 March, unidentified armed men killed a pregnant woman, injured 2 men and kidnapped two other civilians from Murambi, in Kalehe.

notes: On July 3, the Nyatura attacked an FARDC convoy escorting prisoners in Bisoko, Rutshuru. One soldier was killed and another injured.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
actor2: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On June 27, a FARDC soldier killed another at Kasando military camp, in Kirumba. Reasons unclear.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On January 7th, clashes between the FARDC and the Mayi Mayi Hapa na pale resulted in the death of five persons. The attack took place in the villages of Numbi, Mbeya and Masumbalungu, in Kilembwe. The victims are 2 militiamen and 3 civilians, which include the Kilembwe traditional chief and his sons.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On May 27, unidentified armed men killed a shepherd in Burungu.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On April 20, the FARDC clashed with the ADF on the Beni-Kasindi axis, 15km north-east of Beni. Six fatalities in total in two separate attacks outside Beni on that day. These attacks come as a way of discrediting the FARDC owing to the recent recaptures of territory in the 'triangle of death' in between Mbau-Kamango and Eringeti, in Beni. The ADF is moving in small satellite groups around the region, launching attacks were possible, in order to counter the FARDC.

actor2: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On July 21, Mayi Mayi Malaika and Hapa Na Pale militias clashed with the FARDC in Kongolo area, Tanganyika Province. Two killed. After being defeated, they reportedly burned down the villages of Kambinga and Tshibambe, some 65km northwest of Kongolo (approx- coordinates used).

On February 20th, the Hutu Nyatura attacked in Bwito, Mutanda, killing one civilian and burning at least 100 houses. The conflict apparently began when a man was heading to work in the fields and was killed by presumed Hutu Nyatura. Then, youth took up arms and attacked the Hutu families accused of collaborating with the combatants.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On July 5, a DRC naval patrol engaged in battle with a Ugandan patrol in Lake Edward, on the DRC side. In total, 7 people died (3 Ugandan soldiers and 4 civilians).

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: The FARDC clashed with the Mayi Mayi on February 24 in Goma, resulting in 5 deaths (4 rebels and 1 soldier). Apart from injuring 9 rebels who are in the hospital, and capturing another 7, the FARDC also recovered some weapons. 3 soldiers and 1 policeman were injured during the fight.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On the night of April 23, the FARDC clashed with the Mayi Mayi Karakara in the village of Kigoma west of Sange in South Kivu. Two rebels who intended to avenge their brother Karakara who had been killed in Rugeje two weeks prior were killed. Among the rebels was the young brother of Karakara, who had taken up arms after the death of his sibling. The rebels were in the village of Sange when they fell into an ambush by the FARDC.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On April 13, unidentified armed men killed a woman in Vuhumbi, Beni.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
source: Agence France Presse; Radio Okapi; RFI
notes: On April 1st, a priest - Celestin Ngango - was kidnapped along with 9 other people in Nyarukwangara, close to Kiwanja, when he was on his way back from Nyarukwangara, in Rugarama from Easter celebrations. The priest was released five days later after a ransom was paid, but the assailants killed three of the other 9 people that had been kidnapped.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On 13 March, the FARDC killed a civilian in Murambi, Kalehe territory.

actor2: Twiganeho Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)

actor1: Banyamulenge Ethnic Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
actor2: Bafuliru Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)

Around a dozen people were killed, including civilians and militia members. Three days of violence coded between June 16-18.

notes: On May 20, a FARDC soldier shot two civilians in Kisunga, Beni. A man died and another woman was shot to the stomach. On the same day, a soldier shot another man in Lyakobo neighbourhood; the victim died on the spot.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: Between January-April, report of over 10 targeted killings as well as kidnappings and looting by unknown gunmen stationed at Virunga National Park. 10 fatalities spread over four events between January and April.

actor2: Aru Communal Militia (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: Inhabitants of Rodo village in Aru got into clashes with one another over land disputes in the region. The clashes started on Wednesday and lasted for three days. On February 14-15, 6 people were killed with weapons and 6 others were injured in the village of Rodo.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

The attack was repelled by the FARDC, but the clash was described as being of an extremely violent nature. Fatalities split between events.

actor1: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: 17 January. DRC forces and Kamwina Nsapu militia clashed at Kananga airport. An estimated three dead.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On February 15, an unidentified armed group killed a civilian in the commune of Kadutu, in Bukavu, over an exchange of money. The victim was murdered with a chinese grenade. An hour later around 20h, another armed group tried to pillage some boutiques in the Nguba side of the Ibanda commune. 2 other civilians died while trying to save themselves during this attack.

actor1: Police Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On April 14, before the unidentified armed men attacked the FARDC, they forced a man to carry bananas to the Ngadi neighbourhood of Beni, killing him just after.

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
actor2: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)
notes: On January 9th, unidentified gunmen fired at a motorcycle carrying a FARDC soldier on the Butembo-Goma road near Kibirizi locality in Rutshuru territory. The FARDC soldier retaliated and the attackers fled. In the clash, a 37-year-old civilian died after he was hit by a bullet.
On 12 March, 13 bodies were found in a state of decomposition in the collectivities of Bahema Nord, Bahema Banywagi and Bahema Baguru, in Djugu.
On July 22, the ADF detained two men who were going to their fields near Masulukwede village, Beni territory, and killed them.

actor2: Military Forces of Democratic Republic of Congo (2001-)

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)

actor1: Unidentified Armed Group (Democratic Republic of Congo)
notes: On April 29, a group of armed men attacked Mugunga, 10km west of Goma. 6 people were killed and 22 others injured. The attackers raided the kiosks and boutiques.

4 French NGO workers belonging to HYFRO were abducted by presumed Nyatura militiamen on February 17th, between Nyanzala and Kikuku, in Mushikiri. They were returning to their base in Nyanzala when they were ambushed by Nyatura and, out of the 6, 4 were captured. A secondary source reports 2 fatalities.

Around 17 May, a total of 10 Islamist militants were killed in exchanges of fire in North and Central Sinai as part of the on-going "Operation Sinai 2018" campaign. Fatalities split between two events. Another 9 were killed in clashes with the police forces.
The Egyptian police killed six ISIS militants in a shootout in Al Arish.

On 27 April, the Islamic State group claimed to have inflicted casualties in the ranks of the EG army and destroyed a bulldozer and an APC by detonations of two IEDs west of Rafah and east of El-Arish in North Sinai.
Two policemen were killed in an IED attack in Al Arish. Five other conscripts were injured in the attack.
ISIS claims to have repelled attacks by the EG army, clashing with soldiers and destroying some vehicles by IED attacks in Jabal al-Halal. 4 reported dead.

On 21 April, State of Sinai militants claimed to have killed a soldier by sniping east of El-Arish, North Sinai.
On 25 June, IS militants clashed with Egyptian soldiers at the "Sabah barrier" near Rafah port, killing and wounding many of them, before allegedly returning safely to their positions.

Around 11 July. At least 11 Islamist militants were killed in an exchange of fire with police forces in the city of Al-Arish in Egypt's Sinai Peninsula. Two explosives dismantled. The report did not say when the raid took place exactly (report dated 11 July) or whether any security forces were killed or wounded.

Egypt's army said Sunday it had killed 16 militants and detained 34 more since the launch of Operation 'Sinai 2018'. It also destroyed 66 hideouts, 11 pickup vehicles and 31 motorbikes.

ISIS claimed to have executed a civilian they consider a "spy/informant" for the EG army in the area of Rafah.
A recruit soldier lost his life to sniper fire while on duty guarding the church of Abu-Seifein in Al-Arish.
In the week of 18-25 April, eight militants were reportedly killed during military raids in north and central Sinai. 4 fatalities coded in North Sinai and 4 in Central Sinai.
Egypt's army has said it killed 15 militants in crossfire on the sixth day of its latest security operation in Sinai.

source: Al Arabiya; AP International; BBC Monitoring

ISIS claimed sniping two EG soldiers in Kharouba and Karm al-Qawadis east of El-Arish, North Sinai.
ISIS claimed sniping two EG soldiers in Kharouba and Karm al-Qawadis east of El-Arish, North Sinai.

In security operations against Sinai militants "over the past few days" (source date 14 April), 27 were killed, including 12 in a shootout with police and 6 in aerial bombardments. It is unclear if these attacks all occurred at once or separately.
Security forces killed 11 armed ISIS-militants when foiling a suicide attack attempt and during an exchange of fire in Al Arish. In another battle, 3 Egyptian troops were killed by ISIS militants.

On 25 March, police forces killed six Islamist militants in Beheira province. The militants were reported to belong to the Hasam Movement and were blamed for the attack on the Alexandria security chief on 24 March.
On 18 May, presumed State of Sinai militants attacked an Egyptian army position south of Sheikh Zuweyid killing two soldiers.
The EG air force targeted a number of homes and hideouts in the north and west of the Sinai in the framework of the recently launched 'Operation Sinai 2018'. The operations led to 8 dead.

On 27 April, the Islamic State group claimed to have inflicted casualties in the ranks of the EG army and destroyed a bulldozer and an APC by detonations of two IEDs west of Rafah and east of El-Arish in North Sinai.
An inmate in Mukattam police station was reportedly tortured to death by police forces.
Egypt's army has said it killed 7 militants as part of the recently launched 'Sinai 2018' military operation.
On 7 May, the Islamic State group in Egypt (State of Sinai) claimed to have killed an Egyptian soldier by sniper fire near the Riyadh checkpoint, south of Rafah, North Sinai.
Egyptian police forces have killed three suspected militants of Hasm group in an exchange of gunfire in Cairo. 10 members were arrested.
Around 7 April, Egyptian armed forces killed four militants suspected of being members of the State of Sinai militant group in North Sinai. They also detonated 30 IEDs.
Egypt's army has said it killed 3 militants and arrested 244 others during the ongoing security operation in Sinai.
ISIS claimed to have sniped two EG soldiers in the area of Rafah.
ISIS claims to have repelled attacks by the EG army, attacking soldiers by an RPG near Rafah and clashing with them which led to the death of several soldiers.
A quarrel reportedly broke out between political detainees and criminal inmates in Kerdasa police station in Giza which led to at least one dead and several injured.
On 26 June, an employee at Egypt's national broadcasting company was killed when unidentified gunmen entered his home in Arish, northern Sinai, and shot him.

source: Egypt Independent; Al-Ahram Gate; Anadolu Agency
notes: Over the past few days (coded as 20-21 June), the Egyptian army and police supported by the airforce claimed to have killed 32 Islamist militants in two separat incidents in Central and Northern Sinai as a continuation of Comprehensive Sinai 2018 operation. 15 explosive devices destroyed. Police allegedly tortured to death a male from Semari village near Qena.

At least seven army personnel have been killed and six others injured during an Islamic State attack on an army base of the 101 brigade in Al-Arish. Four IS-militants detonated their suicide vests after having exhausted their ammunition.

The Islamic State claimed to have killed around 40 EG military personnel since the start of Operation Sinai 2018 through IED attacks, armed clashes and sniper attacks. Fatalities split between events.

On 8 May, seven people were killed - including a judge, prosecutor, four policemen and a civilian and 17 wounded when a suicide bomber rammed his car into a hotel as security forces opened fire. The car exploded, killing the bomber. A second blast took place 10 minutes later, killing another bomber.

Between 17-29 May, the Egyptian army announced that eight militants had been killed in an operation against State of Sinai militants in Central and North Sinai. Two soldiers were also killed. 10 fatalities spread over 4 events in May.

On 22 and 23 July, the region south of Rafah witnessed clashes between Egyptian armed forces backed by local tribes and State of Sinai militants. During this operation, a Daesh leader, Abou Jaafar al-Maqdesi, was killed.

The Islamic State in Sinai has published a video declaring war on the Palestinian Hamas movement and showing the killing of an IS member who had been allegedly convicted by an IS court of supplying weapons to Hamas's military wing Izz al-Din al-Qassam brigades.
On 25 June, an IED blast targeted a group of soldiers in the Abu Rashoud area south of Sheikh Zuweid during a military operation, killing one soldier and wounding several others.
Islamic State militants dumped the head of a Fawakhiriya tribesman on a main square in al Arish.
ISIS claims to have repelled attacks by the EG army, sniping a soldier in el-Qawadis.
On 9 June, unidentified assailants shot and killed a man in Al-Arish, North Sinai. Their identity and motive was not confirmed.

On 13 June, the Islamic State group reportedly set up an ambush on the International Road west of the town of Arish, killing three Egyptian soldiers. The attack occurred near the salt production facility in Sebika on the road between El-Arish and Bir el-Abed, North Sinai.
On 19 June, the Islamic State group claimed to have killed at least one Egyptian army officer and damaged a Humvee by IED detonation south of El-Arish, North Sinai

On the week of 26 March, six Islamist militants were killed in an operation by the Egyptian army in North Sinai. Two soldiers were also killed in other operations on that week, including at least one on 27 March.
The Egyptian army has killed two militants in central Sinai, arrested two others and destroyed two hideouts and several vehicles.
The Egyptian army killed one ISIS-Sinai militant and destroyed five hideouts in Central Sinai.
10 ISIS militants have been killed on Sunday during a police raid in Arish city.
The EG army killed four ISIS militants in shooutout. One officer and two conscripts were killed as well.
ISIS militants executed a civilian in the Safa neighborhood of Rafah, North Sinai. They claim that the individual worked as an informant on behalf of the EG army.
On 5 June, Egyptian security forces reportedly killed 15 militants in clashes near the Al-Arish ring road.
On 24 March, two policemen were killed in a car bomb explosion targeting the security chief in the Roushdy area of Alexandria. There was no immediate claim of responsibility for the attack.

In a recent statement, the Egyptian Armed Forces reported 21 Islamic State (State of Sinai) militants were killed in Central and North Sinai during the last security operation. Six militants were arrested while seizing weapons and explosives and another 232 suspects arrested. Exact date not reported. Fatalities split between three events.
On 10 June, Egyptian security authorities killed four militants in an exchange of fire in North Sinai's al-Arish, one day after the reported death of a civilian in the same area.
4 soldiers and 10 militants were killed in new fights during military operation 'Sinai 2018' in the Sinai.

On the week of 26 March, six Islamist militants were killed in an operation by the Egyptian army in North Sinai. Two soldiers were also killed in other operations on that week, including at least one on 27 March.
Over 8-11 March, Egypt's military killed 16 militants in Al Arish in the framework of Operation 'Sinai 2018'. Two were killed on their side.

On 18 April, the Islamic State group claimed an IED attack on an M113 armoured personnel carrier near al-Gora airport, south of Sheikh Zuweid town in northern Sinai. The report stated that the attack killed everyone on board.
IS claims to have thwarted an army advance on IS positions south of al-Mayadin village in Sinai, killing two soldiers and wounding others in the fighting.

In security operations against Sinai militants "over the past few days" (source date 14 April), 27 were killed, including 12 in a shootout with police and 6 in aerial bombardments. It is unclear if these attacks all occurred at once or separately.

An Egyptian police officer was killed in an IED blast near Bir el-Abed.

On 8 May, a blast cocurred 10 minutes after another blast that had killed 8 people including the suicide bomber. In the second blast, the suicide bomber died as he detonated his explosives.

ISIS Sinai has claimed an attack on Egyptian military & police in the vicinity of al Arish, killing many through several IED explosions. On 14 May, four people were killed and one injured in an explosion in the New Administrative Capital in New Cairo. The explosion was due to a forgotten landmine left over from previous wars.
Unidentified militants attacked a liquor shop on al-Omraniya Street in Greater Cairo's Giza district, killing two Copts.

Egypt's army killed an Islamic State militant in a raid in North Sinai. Two vehicles and six motorbikes belonging to militants were also destroyed, as well as two warehouses where explosive devices were kept.

Militants killed a Coptic man in the Sinai Peninsula. They did so after seeing a cross tattoo on his wrist. It is supposed that the perpetrators belonged to the Islamic State.

Around 15 March, a military operation carried out by the security forces on Islamic State militants in Al Arish left 36 militants and 4 soldiers killed. Egyptian warplanes hit 12 militant hideouts south of Al Arish during the operation. 345 militants were detained.
ISIS claimed to have sniped two soldiers in the Touma area (Sheikh Zuweid), North Sinai.

Around 17 May, a total of 10 Islamist militants were killed in exchanges of fire in North and Central Sinai as part of the on-going "Operation Sinai 2018" campaign. Fatalities split between two events. Another 9 were killed in clashes with the police forces.
On 28 March, the Islamic State group claimed a suicide bomber attack against Egyptian army vehicles, south of Al-Arish. No reported fatalities (other than bomber).

Between 17-29 May, the Egyptian army announced that eight militants had been killed in an operation against State of Sinai militants in Central and North Sinai. Two soldiers were also killed. 10 fatalities spread over 4 events in May.
The EG army killed four ISIS militants in a shooutout.
On 24 July, Egyptian police forces killed 13 suspected State of Sinai militants in a shootout in al-Arish.
Police captain killed and four others wounded by IED detonation that targeted an armored signal jamming vehicle on the road El-Arish-Qantara. Attack claimed by ISIS.

In a recent statement, the Egyptian Armed Forces reported 21 Islamic State (State of Sinai) militants were killed in Central and North Sinai during the last security operation. Six militants were arrested while seizing weapons and explosives and another 232 suspects arrested. Exact date not reported. Fatalities split between three events.
ISIS militants opened fire and stopped a Tarabin tribesman, abducted him and later killed him, accusing him of cooperating with Egyptian authorities.
On 2 July, an Equatorial Guinean opposition figure who had been jailed for "sedition" was tortured to death in Evinayong Prison, according to his party, the Citizens for Innovation (CI).
Security forces shot a mercenary in the Ebebeyin forest. They believe that he is part of a force that the government is accusing of attempting a coup.

On 28 May, a former army captain and close relative of the Citizens for Innovation opposition party was reportedly murdered at the Malabo Central Prison. The leader claimed it was a state assassination. The ruling party deny the allegation.

Government troops clashed with militants on the Equatorial Guinea-Cameroon border. They accuse the militants of plotting a coup. The government claims that the militant group is made up mercenaries from Sudan, CAR and Chad. One militant was killed in the clash.
The chairman of Al-Dia, a private Muslim school in Asmara, was arrested on 1 November 2017. At the beginning of March 2018, his body was returned to his family.
In Welenchiti town, East Shewa zone, security forces killed 2 people. One of them was local administrative unit leader. It is not known if the victims were protesting at the time.
Several are arrested and two are killed during a 7 day "stay at home strike" in Welkite. The strike began on 13/02, though it is not known when the violence occurred.

Around the week of 25 March in Boke town, west Hararge zone, a young man was tortured by security forces and died after he was taken to hospital in Addis Ababa. He was accused of blocking the road and stirring others to violence. Details are limited.

Over three weeks since the start of April, in Kellam welega zone, Dale wabara woreda, an unknown group of people have been breaking into people's house in rural areas and beating them to death. 12 people have been reported killed and more were seriously injured. 12 fatalities coded over 12 events over the period.
03 March. Security forces kill six protesters in Kelem Wellega over 03/03 and 04/03. No reported violence from protesters.
Students of Salale University protest "for days" (coded as 2 days) for unknown reason. Government forces "shot and killed" [the protesters]. Fatality numbers not provided.

On 13th July, Liyu police paramilitaries attacked a location in Mieso woreda (West Hararge zone), whilst the residents were sleeping. Seven people were reported killed, three of whom are described as Oromia police (assumed also in civilian capacity).
On 27 June, in east Hararge zone, Gumbi Bordede woreda, Liyu police killed two people. No further details.
On 23 and 24 May, Liyu Police attacked four neighbourhoods in the Chinaksen district of Oromia, killing five farmers. They burnt down around 50 homes. Fatalities split between 4 events.

Between the 4-14 June, over 200 people were reportedly killed in ethnic violence in Guji Zone in Southern Ethiopia while over 300,000 were displaced. The violence between the Guji and Gedeo groups that began in April has also resulted in the destruction of schools, churches and private properties. Fatalities spread over 10 events including a fight between Oromos and Gedeos on 4 June that left 10 killed.

Between the 4-14 June, over 200 people were reportedly killed in ethnic violence in Guji Zone in Southern Ethiopia while over 300,000 were displaced. The violence between the Guji and Gedeo groups that began in April has also resulted in the destruction of schools, churches and private properties. Fatalities spread over 10 events including a fight between Oromos and Gedeos on 4 June that left 10 killed.
On 24 April in Bale zone, Laga Hidha, woreda, security forces killed 5 people from the same family. The family is one of the families who were removed from the Somali region.
On 8 June the Liyu police unit attacked three localities in the Oromo region - Qobbo Bikka, Ulanula and Walensu - in Chinaksen district, Oromia, killing three people and wounding three others.
Renewed protest in Oromo region, where opposition leaders were banned from meeting their supporters. One is dead following protests in Dembi Dolo on 24/02.
On 15 May, Liyu police and Somali militia shot 11 protesters dead in Bussa and Lagahida in Fiik zone, Somali. Fatalities split between events.
In East Hararge zone, around Haramaya University, 4 people were killed in security forces shooting for supporting the students in boycott.
On 24 May, Liyu Police shot and killed three protesters in Dollo Ado town in the Somali region as protests against the regional administration intensified.

actor2: Military Forces of Ethiopia (1991-) Agazi Unit
source: Zehabesha; Ethiopian Broadcasting Corporation TV, Addis Ababa, in Amharic 11 Feb 18
notes: Military-Agazi forces killed 10 Internally Displaced People [IDPs] at the Hamaresa [eastern Ethiopia] camp on 11/02 following a protest of a number of IDPs. The camp shelters people [ethnic Oromo] displaced from Somali Regional State. State television claimed "clashes."

On 8 May, two people were killed when shot by security forces in Adola town. They had been involved in a demonstration to the local police station to demand the release of detainees amidst protests against the MIDROC Gold mine.

source: Oromiya Media Network; BBC Worldwide Monitorng; Xinhua
notes: On 21st and 22nd July, violence erupted between mainly Muslim residents of Goba city (Bale zone) and mainly Christian migrant residents of surrounding villages in the area over ownership of a park in Goba town. The violence was ostensibly related to the replacement of a statue in a park traditionally used by the Christians for Timket (Epiphany) celebrations with a statue of a local Muslim hero. Police failed to separate them. The federal army was later sent to prevent clashes from re-occurring. 11 people were reported killed during the weekend (some of whom died later as a result of their injuries), and over 100 injured.
On 15 May, Liyu police and Somali militia shot 11 protesters dead in Bussa and Lagahida in Fiik zone, Somali. Fatalities split between events.
A member of the military killed a civilian in east Hararge zone, Deder woreda, Kobo town. Source dated 15 April.

source: Oromiya Media Network; BBC Worldwide Monitorng; Xinhua
notes: On 21st and 22nd July, violence erupted between mainly Muslim residents of Goba city (Bale zone) and mainly Christian migrant residents of surrounding villages in the area over ownership of a park in Goba town. The violence was ostensibly related to the replacement of a statue in a park traditionally used by the Christians for Timket (Epiphany) celebrations with a statue of a local Muslim hero. Police failed to separate them. The federal army was later sent to prevent clashes from re-occurring. 11 people were reported killed during the weekend (some of whom died later as a result of their injuries), and over 100 injured.
Two protesters are shot and killed by military forces on 22/01, bringing claimed total to 13 over the multiple day ordeal.

In Kelam welega, Dambi dolo city, more than 6 people died in a shooting by Ethiopia security forces. Security forces arrested a man who was announcing a religious conference. A number of people opposed the arrest and security forces responded by opening fire.
On 10 June, Liyu police attacked five more localities in the Chinaksen district - Geellaa, Hosale, Usweyne, Tiiro and Marar - killing four people and wounding another four.
Students of Salale University protest "for days" (coded as 2 days) for unknown reason. Government forces "shot and killed" [the protesters]. Fatality numbers not provided.

On 11 May, a female rights activist was killed while being detained by regional security forces in Kabri Dahar city. An Ethiopian Somali news outlet claimed pictures circulated showed wounds around her neck pointing to a death by hanging. It was said to be a punitive measure against her outspoken relatives of the Somali regional government.
On or after 1st July, a group purporting to be a faction of the OLF attacked locations in Welega zone, killing four police officers.
Following numerous reports of assault upon protesters, a number of demonstrators attacked security forces. Five deaths reported among the security forces.
TPLF security forces shot and killed three people in Alem Tena, East Shewa while holding a sit in protest at a flagpole to mourn the death of protesters in Woldia and Moyale in the weekend.

Over three weeks since the start of April, in Kellam welega zone, Dale wabara woreda, an unknown group of people have been breaking into people's house in rural areas and beating them to death. 12 people have been reported killed and more were seriously injured. 12 fatalities coded over 12 events over the period.

On 9 June, Liyu police officers returned to the three localities they attacked the day before and continued their attacks as well as attacking two more - Darbiga and Gololcha - killing seven people and wounding 17.

actor1: Military Forces of Ethiopia (1991-) Agazi Unit
notes: On 15 April, a total of four people were killed by the Agazi units in the Guji zone in Oromia. One of the four was killed in Bule Hora town and three people from the town were also wounded.

Federal security forces killed a young man in Diredawa on the night of 07/02 for unknown reason. His funeral the following day turned into protest. The federal security forces are firing at the protesters. No confirmed number of death and injury reported.
On 10th July, Liyu police killed one Oromo and wounded another, at Mieso woreda in Western Hararge.

On 3 April, three security forces were killed by an grenade thrown by an unknown person as they were "humiliating" people in Kelam Welaga zone, Dambi Dolo. Following their death the people from the area reported shootings.
07 March. Liyu forces move into Meda Welabu, engage in a battle with Oromo militia. Two Oromo and three Liyu dead. Before departing the Liyu militia stole 150 cattle.
In East Hararge zone, Babile woreda, Liyu police killed one person and wounded three persons.

Over three weeks since the start of April, in Kellam welega zone, Dale wabara woreda, an unknown group of people have been breaking into people's house in rural areas and beating them to death. 12 people have been reported killed and more were seriously injured. 12 fatalities coded over 12 events over the period.

Over 13-15 June, riots reported between the Sidama and Wolaita groups in Hawassa town following the kidnapping and killing of two people and violence at a new year festival. Residences were burnt and ransacked. Total of 10 people killed from 13-15 June.
02 March. Three are killed by security forces in Gonder. It is not known if the victims were protesting at the time of attack.
On 13 June, some people were reported killed in clashes in the town of Kebele, Kibbutin. No further details.

On 21 May in Bate woreda, Wollo zone, Afar region militias have been attacking Oromo people on the border in order to expand their border. 3 members of Afar Militias were killed in clashes that opposed the two.
On 4th July, Liyu police attacked Chinaksen woreda, eastern Hararge zone and clashed with Oromo militiamen. 9 killed including 7 Liyu. One Oromo injured.
Four are killed during continued violent protests against the TPLF government.

Over three weeks since the start of April, in Kellam welega zone, Dale wabara woreda, an unknown group of people have been breaking into people's house in rural areas and beating them to death. 12 people have been reported killed and more were seriously injured. 12 fatalities coded over 12 events over the period.
On 5 June, Liyu police crossed the border and killed an 11 year old girl by cutting her throat with knife in Bale zone, Mada Wolabu woreda.

Between the 4-14 June, over 200 people were reportedly killed in ethnic violence in Guji Zone in Southern Ethiopia while over 300,000 were displaced. The violence between the Guji and Gedeo groups that began in April has also resulted in the destruction of schools, churches and private properties. Fatalities spread over 10 events including a fight between Oromos and Gedeos on 4 June that left 10 killed.

On 25 May, police clashed with residents in Arbaminch town in Southern Ethiopia as authorities demolished thousands of houses that they said were illegaly built. Over 20 people were reported injured. On the same day police shot and killed a man in Burie who intervened to stop a staff member breaking down houses. 4,000 people reportedly detained.

4 July. The Liyu police with the Somali region in Eastern Ethiopia attacked predominantly Oromo residents of Babile and Chinaksen in East Hararghe killing at least three, setting 60 houses on fire and displacing hundreds of people. 1 fatality reported in Babile.

Between 12-15 June, over 100 people were injured in Wolkitie town, 93 miles southwest of the capital Addis Ababa in clashes between the Qebena and Gurage groups. Thirty homes and four vehicles were also set ablaze. The Qebenas claim the town belongs to them and demand that the Gurages should leave the town. One death reported on 13 June.

On 25 June, one person was killed in violence between Berta people and Oromo/Amhara groups in Asosa, Benishangul-Gumuz Regional State. A total of 14 people were reported killed in violence in Asosa over 25-27 June.
On 16 March, soldiers dressed in Liyu police uniform reportedly killed 5 members of a family inthe village of Burka Dare in Seweyna district, Bale zone. Villagers fled.
On 4 April, in East Guji zone, federal police beat three young people and threw them into a ditch. One died while the others received hospital treatment.

On 3 July, Ethiopian and Sudanese troops engaged in a brief battle after Sudanese soldiers killed and injured several Ethiopian farmers. There were deaths on both sides. Seven Ethiopians including members of the army have been sent to Genda Wuha Hospital in Metema after the brief exchange of fire.

On 23 June, an unidentified man attempted to throw a grenade at the new PM Abiy Ahmed during a rally in the capital before being apprehended by police. The grenade still detonated resulting in 2 deaths and 150 injuries.
On 12th July, Liyu police clashed with Oromo forces in Chinaksen woreda (East Harerge zone). Seven Liyu police were killed, as well as two Oromo fighters. Two Oromo were also injured.

source: Twitter.com in English 0001 gmt 25 Jan 18; ESAT; The Reporter; Addis Standard
notes: Anti-TPLF protests in Kobo continue. The demonstrations became violent. A reported 3 dead following security force intervention. A second source claims nine protester dead. Reports in the following week indicated that 60 deaths occurred over the course of the week through the area. Reports of police making "arbitrary arrests."
10 are killed in clashes between anti-TPLF protest and security forces in Weldiya, Kobo, Mersa and Sirinka on 28/01.

Ethiopia's Defence Minister declared on 07 March that 17 security forces have been killed since the beginning of government's state of emergency on 16/02. (Five security force deaths have been previously recorded). Specific details, such as time and location not provided.
ONLA fighters claim to have killed 11 members of Ethiopian military force on 25/01 at Habawein in Degahabur.

In East Shewa zone, Bose woreda, Wolanchiti town, Ethiopian security forces killed one person and wounded 3 more. The victims were taking part in a protest/business boycott against the TPLF government.

Over three weeks since the start of April, in Kellam welega zone, Dale wabara woreda, an unknown group of people have been breaking into people's house in rural areas and beating them to death. 12 people have been reported killed and more were seriously injured. 12 fatalities coded over 12 events over the period.

Over three weeks since the start of April, in Kellam welega zone, Dale wabara woreda, an unknown group of people have been breaking into people's house in rural areas and beating them to death. 12 people have been reported killed and more were seriously injured. 12 fatalities coded over 12 events over the period.

Anti-TPLF protest continue in Weldiya. Reports of stone throwing on behalf of protesters. Security forces opened fire on a group of the demonstrators, killing between 7-12. Note: it is possible 4 of the 12 were fatally wounded on the previous day of protests. A later report claimed 11 dead over two days. Several arrests made. Protests continued the following day during their victim's funeral procession. Reports in the following week indicated that 60 deaths occurred over the course of the week through the area.

On 19th July, a mob attacked journalists travelling to Addis Ababa, at Mieso woreda (West Hararge zone), accusing them of being spies. The driver of their vehicle died later in hospital, and five other crew were injured. Nobody has been arrested.

On 26 June, 7 people were killed in violence between Berta people and Oromo/Amhara groups in Asosa, Benishangul-Gumuz Regional State. A total of 14 people were reported killed in violence in Asosa over 25-27 June.

October 2017 - April 2018: Clashes have been reported since October 2017 between Amhara and Gumuz communities after the death of an ethnic Gumuz that was blamed on the Amhara side. 13 people were killed, 49 injured and 149 houses of the Amharas were set on fire since the conflict began in October. 14 fatalities coded over 8 events between October 2017-April 2018
11 March. Security forces kill one and injure another in Moyale the day following a series of attacks which killed between 9-13.
On 23 and 24 May, Liyu Police attacked four neighbourhoods in the Chinaksen district of Oromia, killing five farmers. They burnt down around 50 homes. Fatalities split between 4 events.
14 March. A civilian is found shot in Ginchi woreda, Chilimo. Perpetrators not known.

On 20 April in Moyale town, Borana woreda, a group of young men who were sent by the Liyu police to start violations were arrested and two of them were killed by security forces as they were trying to escape.

Massive protest in Gurage zone, Wolkite city, turned into violent after security forces killed one person and wounded 3 more. 7 government vehicles were burned down also city administration building and all the documents in it were burned down.
07 March. In Jimma Zone, Omo Nada woreda, security forces kill two civilians.

In East Hararge zone, Chinaksan woreda, Liyu police and Ethiopian security forces simultaneously attacked the people of Qobo(Kobo) area. Two persons died from local areas and 3 people from Liyu police were captured alive.

On 13 April, scores of people were reportedly feared dead and thousands displaced in renewed clashes between the Guji and Gedeo communities in Southern Ethiopia between Finchawa and Awassa. Gedeo people were being forced out of their villages in their thousands.
02 March. Reports of security forces "arresting and killing people" in Meyumuluke. Two deaths reported, one injury.
On 20th July, Liyu Police paramilitaries killed 5 Oromo citizens in Chinaksen woreda (East Hararge zone), and wounded many more.

10 are killed in clashes between anti-TPLF protest and security forces in Weldiya, Kobo, Mersa and Sirinka on 28/01. Reports of detainments and executions in Mersa, as well as the killing of a judge at the hand of protesters.

In west Arsi zone, Kokosa woreda, 3 people died in the conflict between Oromo police and Local Qerros. A taxi driver tried to hit someone and Qerros retaliated, kicking off a short conflict. Police became involved, sparking clashes that led to the death of the three.
On 8 May, three people were shot and killed by security forces in Togwachalle town in Eastern Ethiopia supposedly while protesting against Abdi Illey.

On 9 June, Liyu police officers returned to the three localities they attacked the day before and continued their attacks as well as attacking two more - Darbiga and Gololcha - killing seven people and wounding 17.

On 24 May, clashes between Liyu police and Oromo people in Chinaksen woreda, East Harage zone continued. 4 more people were killed from Liyu police. Ethiopian security forces were unarming Oromo people at the same time when Liyu police were attacking the people.
On 10 June, Liyu police attacked five more localities in the Chinaksen district - Geellaa, Hosale, Usweyne, Tiiro and Marar - killing four people and wounding another four.

Anti-government, anti-state of emergency protests reported in Gurage area, affecting the towns of Welkite, Indibir and Agena. Violence reported. Three dead among the towns. Date(s) not known - source dated 21/02. Several arrests reported.

Between the 4-14 June, over 200 people were reportedly killed in ethnic violence in Guji Zone in Southern Ethiopia while over 300,000 were displaced. The violence between the Guji and Gedeo groups that began in April has also resulted in the destruction of schools, churches and private properties. Fatalities spread over 10 events including a fight between Oromos and Gedeos on 4 June that left 10 killed.

On 16 May, unidentified gunmen killed the country manager of Nigeria's Dangote Industries and a secretary and driver when they were attacked in Inchini near Mugher town, Ada Berger district, West Shewa. The manager was Indian and his colleagues Ethiopian.
In west Hararge zone, Miesso woreda, Liyu police killed a man and wounded his son.

October 2017 - April 2018: Clashes have been reported since October 2017 between Amhara and Gumuz communities after the death of an ethnic Gumuz that was blamed on the Amhara side. 13 people were killed, 49 injured and 149 houses of the Amharas were set on fire since the conflict began in October. 14 fatalities coded over 8 events between October 2017-April 2018
On 24 April, a young man was killed in Eerer Gota. The source did not state the perpetrator.

Over three weeks since the start of April, in Kellam welega zone, Dale wabara woreda, an unknown group of people have been breaking into people's house in rural areas and beating them to death. 12 people have been reported killed and more were seriously injured. 12 fatalities coded over 12 events over the period.
04 March. Security forces shot and killed a man and injured his son in Guder.
On 21st July, one person was killed and another wounded when an unidentified group fired at civilians in Dembi Dollo woreda (Kelem Wellega zone).
On 30 June, in Metema, the Sudanese army killed five farm workers in an unprovoked attack.

In Guto Gidda woreda, Uke town (near Nekemt), one man was killed and 3 people wounded by security forces. It is not known if the individuals were protesting at the time. There were additional reports of security forces breaking into homes and attacking residents.

On 4 June, in Guji zone, Hambalawa Mana, Gedeo and Burji people started a fight with Oromo people on the border. At least 10 people were killed, and many were removed from their homes and their properties were destroyed.

On 10 June, Liyu police attacked five more localities in the Chinaksen district - Geellaa, Hosale, Usweyne, Tiiro and Marar - killing four people and wounding another four.

05 March. Security forces shot and killed three people (protesters). Two were killed in Jimma, according to Oromo activists, while the third was killed in West Hararghe, in a locality called Chiro.

On 4th July, Liyu police attacked Oromo civilians in Bule Hora woreda, Bornea zone. Two civilians were killed, and three injured.
16 March, seven soldiers were killed when they attempted to seize guns from local farmers in North Gondar Zone of the Amhara Region.

Over 13-15 June, riots reported between the Sidama and Wolaita groups in Hawassa town following the kidnapping and killing of two people and violence at a new year festival. Residences were burnt and ransacked. Total of 10 people killed from 13-15 June.

On February 07, 2018,in East Hararge zone, Chinaksan woreda, at Qobo(Kobo) Biqa(Bika), 10 year old boy was killed in the shooting between local militia and Liyu police.

Ethiopian security forces killed one student and wounded two more in Arsii zone, Lemo woreda, Bokoji town. Students were singing in group as they were going back home from school, but security forces did not understand the language the students were speaking and thought they were protesting.
04 March. Three people killed by security forces including a man taken from his house.

Anti-government, anti-state of emergency protests reported in Gurage area, affecting the towns of Welkite, Indibir and Agena. Violence reported. Three dead among the towns. Date(s) not known - source dated 21/02. Several arrests reported.
On 25th July, Liyu Police attacked Oromo forces in Chinaksen woreda (East Hararge zone). Four Liyu Police paramilitaries were killed in the fighting.

Day four: One person was killed and 20 others wounded when snipers of the TPLF/Agazi forces indiscriminately shot at protesters in the city of Nekemte. It was additionally reported a protester threw a hand grenade against security forces. Protests in the city began on 24/02.
Around 12 June, the Sudanese army killed several Ethiopian farmers on a disputed farmland on the border between the two countries. Further violence was reported towards the end of the month.
